So ive been playing this for a while, more than addictive! Im not so good with the spaceship thing, I can get stuff into a rough orbit, but getting to the Mun is beyond me right now. Ive been having way more fun flying aircraft, I must invest in a joystick...

Anyways, ive set myself a target, to get around Kerbin atleast once. So far ive only got about half way:

Has anyone topped 720km? Im aiming to go further now

This is the beast:

Typically, its started off nice and slender, almost pretty looking. Unfortunately it lacked the range needed, so I added more fuel, then it lacked the power, so I added more/bigger engines and added a takeoff booster. Then it lacked lift, so I extended the wings, and even added more wings. After all this, it was completely unstable, so I had to go back and move all the wings around, then it would fly. Its very very stable, only downside is it tries to climb until it backflips. Even with the autopilot on itll slowly do that, so you have to keep an eye on things.
I made it all the way around Kerbin with a glider.
In principle, the infiniglide bug allows for infinite range.

I did not use

a) magic turbine

SAS power

I simply took off via one SRB, and pointed the nose up at 20 degrees.

My record holder for distance is also my record for altitude and speed. 1330km distance before I intentionally crashed it (it was taking too long), 29500m altitude, and 750m/s airspeed. And my friend kept releasing my drop tanks early while I wasn\'t looking.

This thread (as well as the rest of the challenges for longest distance in atmosphere) simply will not work.

The 'infinite glide' glitch can not be prevented at this time. The drag equations are simply incorrect, meaning any plane (or glider) could be using the glitch partially, or completely.

Point being, the challenge is invalid, because any plane with any parts that affect drag (all of them) consists as 'cheating', because all of them are taking advantage of drag in one way or another.
